title: 107_hr54
content: The Act may be cited as the "Mandates Information Act of 2001". Congress finds that before acting on proposed private sector mandates, it should carefully consider their effects on consumers, workers, and small businesses. Congress has often lacked adequate information on the costs of these mandates, focusing only on their benefits. The Unfunded Mandates Reform Act of 1995 increased awareness of intergovernmental mandates without affecting existing environmental, public health, or safety laws. Implementing this Act will enhance awareness of prospective private sector mandates without harming the environment or public health. Private sector mandates can result in higher prices, lower wages, reduced benefits, and hiring disincentives for small businesses. The purposes of this Act are to improve Congress' deliberation on private sector mandates by providing more information and ensuring focused deliberation, and to help distinguish between harmful and beneficial mandates. The Act aims to enhance Congress' consideration of private sector mandates by providing additional information on their impact, including on consumers, workers, and small businesses. The Act aims to enhance Congress' consideration of private sector mandates by providing additional information on their impact, including on consumers, workers, and small businesses. This includes an analysis of the effect of Federal private sector mandates on worker wages, benefits, employment opportunities, hiring practices, expansion, and profitability of businesses with 100 or fewer employees. The estimate prepared under this paragraph is not considered in determining whether the direct costs of all Federal private sector mandates will exceed the threshold. The bill aims to improve Congress' assessment of private sector mandates by providing more information on their impact. Amendments are made to the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 regarding point of order and threshold amounts for private sector mandates. The bill makes amendments to the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to enhance Congress' evaluation of private sector mandates. It includes provisions to increase direct costs of Federal private sector mandates and adjust threshold amounts for mandates. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to remove references to "intergovernmental" in various sections. Additionally, Clause 11(b) of rule XVIII of the Rules of the House of Representatives is amended. Rule XVIII of the House of Representatives is amended to include section 424(a)(1) or (b)(1). This amendment is enacted by Congress as an exercise of their rulemaking powers, allowing each House to change rules as needed. SEC. 5. FEDERAL INTERGOVERNMENTAL MANDATE. Amendment to the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 regarding provisions in legislation, statutes, or regulations impacting states.
